title: preferred, prefered... | WordReference Forums
text: Hi there! 'preferred' and 'prefered' ... Are they both correct? According to the rule found here: post 10813 Travelling/Traveling In American English, in a multisyllabic word with a final consonant directly preceded by a single vowel, that consonant does not get doubled if the stress does not fall on the last syllable. ... 'prefered' should not be used since the stress does fall on the last syllable, even in American English... However, I find it is used, although less common... So... what do you prefer? The same question may apply to: referred/refered preferring/prefering 'preferred' and 'prefered' ... Are they both correct?
